questions.text: A 56-year-old patient presents with chronic constipation, increased thirst, and pain on the left side of the back. X Ray KUB showed renal stones. Her blood was sent for routine investigations and an ECG was taken. What will be the most likely finding on ECG?
questions.correct_answer: A. Prolongation of the PR interval
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Prolongation of the PR interval These features are most likely pointing towards hypercalcemia – increased thirst, constipation ( abdominal groans ), and renal stones. Prolongation of the PR interval is seen in hypercalcemia.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B- Hypocalcemia typically prolongs the QT interval. Option: C - hypocalcemia causes Torsades de pointes. Option: D - Tall, tented T waves are seen in hyperkalemia.

questions.text: A patient is on tab hydrochlorothiazide for his hypertension. A routine ecg was done and showed prominent U waves. What is the most likely electrolyte abnormality the patient is suffering from?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hypokalemia Hypokalemia prolongs ventricular repolarization, often with prominent U waves.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A Prolongation of the PR interval and shortening of the PR interval is seen in Option: C. Hypocalcemia typically prolongs the QT interval and may cause Torsades de pointes. Option: D. Hyperkalemia causes narrowing and peaking (tenting) of the T waves, diminution in P wave amplitude and widening of the QRS interval.

questions.text: A 62-year-old female patient presents with constipation and increased thirst. She has past history of kidney stones which were managed conservatively. ECG was taken and showed changes in hypercalcemia. Which of the following is incorrect about ECG findings in certain conditions?

options.label: A
options.text: Digitalis shows scooping of the ST-T wave complex

options.label: B
options.text: Subarachnoid haemorrhage causes wide T-wave inversions

options.label: D
options.text: Severe hypokalemia causes the sine-wave pattern

questions.correct_answer: D. Severe hypokalemia causes the sine-wave pattern
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Severe hypokalemia causes the sine-wave pattern Severe hyperkalemia eventually causes cardiac arrest with a slow sinusoidal type of mechanism (“sine-wave” pattern) followed By asystole.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Digitalis shortens the QT interval, often with a characteristic “scooping” of the ST–T-wave complex. Option: B. Marked QT prolongation, sometimes with deep, wide T-wave inversions, may occur with intracranial bleeds, particularly subarachnoid haemorrhage known as the “CVA T-wave” pattern. Option: C. Systemic hypothermia Prolongs repolarization and causes convex elevation of the J point known as the Osborn wave.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male patient presents with breathlessness for two days. He is a chronic smoker for 20 years and has a known case of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. His saturation on room air was 86% and improved to 92% with 2 L O2 via nasal cannula. What findings will be seen in his ECG?

options.label: A
options.text: Peak to trough QRS amplitudes of≤ 5 mm in limb leads

options.label: B
options.text: Peak to trough QRS amplitudes ≤10 mm in the chest leads.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Both A and B Conditions including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, pericardial or pleural effusions, infiltrative cardiomyopathies, and anasarca cause Low QRS voltage in ECG which is arbitrarily defined as peak-to-trough QRS amplitudes of ≤ 5 mm in the six limb leads and/or ≤ 10 mm in the chest leads.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: C . Prominent U waves area feature of hypokalemia.

questions.text: A 70-year-old female patient presents with perioral numbness. On examination, twitching of facial muscles on tapping on the cheek can be elicited. What findings in ecg are likely to be found in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Prolongation of QT interval Post-menopausal woman with perioral numbness and twitching of facial muscles on percussion over the cheek or branches of the facial nerve, known as the Chvostek sign, is highly suggestive of hypocalcemia. Hypocalcemia typically prolongs the QT interval and causes Torsades de pointes.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Prolongation of the PR interval is seen in hypercalcemia. Option: C. Tall, tented T waves are seen in hyperkalemia Option: D. Systemic hypothermia Prolongs repolarization and causes convex elevation of the J point known as the Osborn wave.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient is on multiple medications. He has a history of diabetes, hypertension, previous history of an episode of myocardial infarction. He is currently on metformin, hydrochlorothiazide, amlodipine, aspirin and atorvastatin. His routine ECG shows the presence of tall U waves. Which of the following is incorrect regarding U waves?

options.label: A
options.text: Normal U wave has ≤1 mm amplitude

options.label: B
options.text: Dofetilide leads to an increase in U-wave amplitude

options.label: C
options.text: Quinidine leads to reversal of U wave

options.label: D
options.text: May lead to torsades de pointes

questions.correct_answer: C. Quinidine leads to reversal of U wave
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Quinidine leads to reversal of U wave Quinidine causes an increase in U wave amplitude and not reversal of U waves.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. The normal U wave is a small, rounded deflection, ≤1 mm, that follows the T wave and usually has the same polarity as the T wave. Option: B. - Drugs like dofetilide, amiodarone, sotalol, quinidine cause an abnormal increase in U-wave amplitude . Option: D. - Very prominent U waves are a marker of increased susceptibility to torsades de pointes
